Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Digitization TCN: Developing a Centralized Digital Archive of Vouchered Animal Communication Signals
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to establish a thematic collection network that will digitize and make accessible media recordings associated with physical voucher specimens, broadly organized around the research theme of understanding the evolution and ecology of communication signals. Research on these questions has been challenged by the relative inaccessibility of the signal recordings and their associated physical specimens. This project will meet this challenge by partnering together multiple biological research collections and the Macaulay Library of Natural Sounds, the world's largest scientific archive of animal signal recordings. Collectively, these institutions will co-curate and make accessible digitized and vouchered recordings of the communication signals of birds, frogs, fish and insects, and will establish direct and transparent links across collections between physical voucher specimens and their digitized recordings. This project will make accessible digital audio recordings of animal signals that can be used to address a host of scientific questions, including the responses of animals to anthropogenic noise and other human activities. By providing a useful co-curation system and encouraging collection of recordings along with physical specimens, this project will have a transformative influence on the way that researchers collect and use biological specimens in the future, and will serve as a useful model for collections facing similar co-curation challenges.

This project will also provide materials for extensive educational outreach at all age levels, and will have significant conservation impacts because the digitized material will contribute directly to our ability to assess and monitor biodiversity. Finally, this project will expand biological collection methods and help train the "next generation" of museum curators, collectors, and researchers. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific value of physical specimens is enhanced substantially when associated with ancillary data and assets, and by the same token ancillary data and materials are of limited value unless associated with a physical voucher specimen. Audio and video recordings of animal signals are one such asset: these recordings are incredibly valuable to researchers addressing a host of questions regarding the evolution of communication signals, including the responses of organisms to anthropogenic noise and other perturbations, and such recordings are routinely collected by museum collectors and other researchers. Yet, despite this research value, vouchered audio recordings currently are a resource that is underappreciated, vastly underutilized, and prohibitively under-curated. This in part is due to the fact that most biological research collections lack the specialized equipment, infrastructure, and expertise needed to digitize, preserve, store and manage audio specimens, and audio archives capable of handling audio specimens are often isolated from traditional research collections. As a result, in the vast majority of cases explicit connections between recordings and their physical vouchers do not exist. This project helped address this need by building a collaborative partnership between a number of biological research collections with extensive specimen collections and the Macaulay Library at the Cornell Lab of Ornithology. 

 

Specifically, this award established a thematic collection network (TCN) that digitized and made accessible media recordings associated with physical voucher specimens, broadly organized around the research theme: “understanding the tempo and mode of animal signal evolution”. The TCN is a partnership between multiple biological research collections that routinely collect media specimens along with physical specimens, and the Macaulay Library, the world’s largest scientific archive of animal signal recordings. Collectively, these institutions are now co-curating and delivering digitized and vouchered recordings of animal communication signals (vocalizations and electric organ discharges), and in collaboration with the national digitization center iDigBio, they have establish direct and transparent links across collections between physical voucher specimens and their digitized recordings. This project has addressed three inter-related problems currently facing biological collections – the need to digitize and organize valuable recordings currently under-curated, the general lack of database connections to their associated voucher specimens, and the difficulty of access to these materials by the scientific community – and has established workable protocols and tools to facilitate growth of the TCN and help prevent such problems from arising again in the future.

 

This project is having a transformative influence on the way that researchers collect and use biological specimens in the future. First, this TCN serves as a useful model for collections facing similar co-curation challenges, as the approach can be extended to other taxa and other types of ancillary materials that require specialized expertise. Second, this project has developed best practices and data standards for collecting and archiving vouchered audio recordings and other media types. Third, this TCN addresses directly an emerging and rapidly growing source of data loss – audio specimens deposited on internet bulletin boards rather than in curated scientific collections – through an educational outreach component aimed at researchers as well as the broader public. Fourth, this TCN is contributing to broader educational outreach by providing materials to extend further the already substantial educational outreach activities of the partner institutions. Fifth, this project will have significant conservation impacts, because vouchered audio recordings contribute directly to our ability to assess and monitor biodiversity. Finally, a number of students participated in this project, and thus this TCN project has helped to train the “next generation” of museum curators, collectors, and researchers.
